channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Josh Shapiro Writes That Harris Team Asked if He Had Ever Been an Israeli Agent
item.description: In his new memoir, the Pennsylvania governor suggests that when Kamala Harris’s team vetted him to be her running mate, aides focused on Israel to an extent he found offensive.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new memoir by Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania goes into detail about his experience being vetted to be former Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate in 2024.

item.title: Man Acquitted of Shining a Laser at Marine One With Trump Aboard
item.description: A jury found the man, Jacob Samuel Winkler, not guilty after just 35 minutes of deliberation. He was charged in September with pointing a laser at an aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.category: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)
item.media:description: A Washington man was charged in September with pointing a laser at Marine One, the presidential helicopter, while President Trump was aboard.

item.title: Noem Denies Use of Chemical Agents in Minnesota Protests, Then Backtracks
item.description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, said officers had not used pepper spray and similar measures limited by a judge’s order, then was confronted with a video that showed chemical agents deployed.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:description: Kristi Noem, the secretary of homeland security, at the White House last week.

item.title: Springsteen Denounces ICE Deployments and Renee Good’s Killing
item.description: In a surprise appearance in New Jersey, the musician dedicated his song “The Promised Land” to Ms. Good, who was killed by an ICE agent in Minneapolis this month.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Bruce Springsteen performing in Los Angeles in October.

item.title: Pentagon Tells 1,500 Troops to Prepare for Possible Deployment to Minnesota
item.description: But President Trump has already backed away from a threat to invoke the Insurrection Act in response to protests against the killing of a woman by a federal immigration agent.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis last week. The use of military force on domestic soil in the United States is rare, and it is usually reserved only for the most extreme situations.

item.title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Trump Recaps His Recent ‘Legal-ish’ Activities
item.description: The first episode of 2026, hosted by Finn Wolfhard of “Stranger Things,” satirized that hit Netflix series and conjured a Harry Potter reboot à la “Heated Rivalry.”
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff

item.title: Buttigieg, Booker Lead Midterm Democratic Health Care Push
item.description: The potential 2028 presidential candidates showcased a Democratic midterm strategy that would assail G.O.P. votes in favor of cutting Medicaid and allowing health care subsidies to expire.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning and Allison Braden
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: Pete Buttigieg argued that pressure from Wisconsinites had led their Republican congressional representative to vote in support of extending enhanced health care subsidies.

item.title: Inside Trump’s Deportation Machine
item.description: Data obtained by The New York Times illustrates the differences between President Trump’s and President Biden’s approaches to deportations. Our data reporter Albert Sun describes what we found.
item.dc:creator: Albert Sun, Gilad Thaler, Melanie Bencosme, Joey Sendaydiego, Edward Vega, Jon Miller and Thomas Trudeau

item.title: Under Patel, F.B.I. Scours Its Records to Discredit Trump Opponents
item.description: As the F.B.I. has added payback to its portfolio, Republican lawmakers like Senator Charles E. Grassley have emerged as a clearinghouse for leaks and whistle-blowers.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Under Kash Patel, F.B.I. personnel have worked to paint a damning, one-sided narrative intended to discredit and embarrass federal law enforcement officials who investigated Donald J. Trump and his allies.

item.title: Trump Backs a Potential Primary Challenger to Bill Cassidy, a G.O.P. Senator
item.description: The president urged Representative Julia Letlow of Louisiana to run against Mr. Cassidy, in a move that is likely to further complicate his relationship with Senate Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Bill Cassidy, Republican of Louisiana, has sometimes criticized President Trump and voted to convict him in his second impeachment trial.

item.title: Virginia’s New Governor Moves Swiftly to Overhaul State University Boards
item.description: Abigail Spanberger, a Democrat, appointed new board members at three state schools, hours after she was sworn in as Virginia’s first female governor.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: Gov. Abigail Spanberger of Virginia took a variety of executive actions during her first few hours in office on Saturday.

item.title: These Are the 12 States Vying to Kick Off Democrats’ 2028 Contest
item.description: There were a few surprises, and subtle regional digs, as Democratic state parties angled for early spots on the next presidential primary calendar. The New York Times reviewed their applications.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein, Lisa Lerer and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigning in Mount Pleasant, Iowa, in 2020. Democrats in the state are hoping to keep it at the front of the party’s presidential nominating calendar.

item.title: White House Warns CBS: Air Trump Interview in Full, or ‘We’ll Sue’
item.description: In previously unreported remarks, the White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told CBS News that Mr. Trump would “sue” the news outlet if it did not air an interview unedited.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:description: Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, at a briefing at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Announces New Tariffs on Some European Countries in Greenland Standoff
item.description: The president escalated his drive to take charge of the Danish territory, targeting Denmark and seven other European countries with a 10 percent rate.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh, Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said the new tariff would increase to 25 percent on June 1 if his demands were not met.

item.title: A Trump Veto Leaves Republicans in Colorado Parched and Bewildered
item.description: The first veto of the president’s second term killed legislation that would have brought clean water to some of the most conservative parts of the state. Residents wonder why.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy and Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times
item.media:credit: Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ed Brown can’t consume water that comes out of the tap at his house because it is contaminated with unsafe levels of radium and uranium. He fills jugs of drinking water at Rocky Ford Food Market in Rocky Ford, Colo.

item.title: After Renee Good’s Killing, Some Conservatives Scorn Liberal Women
item.description: Vocal Trump supporters are demonizing Renee Good, her partner and their allies, with some even using an acronym: AWFUL, or Affluent White Female Urban Liberal.
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial near the site where Renee Good was shot and killed in Minneapolis.

item.title: Court Blocks Trump Administration From Freezing Food Stamps in Minnesota
item.description: With tensions high between the White House and the state, the ruling temporarily halted plans to withhold over $129 million in funding.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A food pantry in Detroit Lakes, Minn., last year.

item.title: DOJ Opens Criminal Investigation Into Minnesota Governor and Minneapolis Mayor
item.description: The Justice Department’s investigation is a major escalation in the state-federal battle over the conduct of immigration agents in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer, Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacob Frey, the mayor of Minneapolis, at a news conference this month. He and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota are being investigated by the Justice Department, according to a senior law enforcement official.

item.title: Trump Announces Members for Gaza ‘Board of Peace,’ Including Rubio and Kushner
item.description: The president also tapped a U.S. general to lead an international peacekeeping force that will be deployed to disarm Hamas and occupy Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City on Tuesday. Most of Gaza has been destroyed by Israeli bombardment over more than two years of war.

item.title: AI Attack Ad in Texas Senate Race Shows John Cornyn Dancing With Jasmine Crockett
item.description: A video from Ken Paxton, a Republican primary challenger to Senator John Cornyn of Texas, depicted A.I.-generated imagery of the senator twirling with Jasmine Crockett, a Democratic Senate candidate.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, is challenging Senator John Cornyn, a fellow Republican.
